title: Include trait signature in "type annotations needed" error message.

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: E-needs-mentor
labels.description: Call for participation: This issue is in need of a mentor.

body:
With the following code:
```rust
use std::process::{Command, Stdio};                                             
                                                                                
fn main() {                                                                     
    let process = Command::new("wc")                                            
                          .stdout(Stdio::piped())                               
                          .spawn()                                              
                          .or_else(|err| {                                      
                              panic!("oh no: {:?}", err);                        
                          }).unwrap();                                          
}   
```
[You will get the error message](https://play.rust-lang.org/?gist=521c1d4ec4eb4f98cb18118cd3de1d99&version=nightly):
```
error[E0282]: type annotations needed
 --> src/main.rs:7:28
  |
7 |                           .or_else(|err| {
  |                            ^^^^^^^ cannot infer type for `F`
```

I can't help but feel that this is not useful, because it's not clear what `F` is.

A novice user would be baffled. If we are lucky they might look at the signature of `or_else` to see if `F` is defined there. It is:
```rust
fn or_else<F, O>(self, op: O) -> Result<T, F>
where
    O: FnOnce(E) -> Result<T, F>, 
```

I think it would be useful to include this signature in the error message, so that the user can see what `F` is without having to look it up in the docs.

Indeed, this error is fixed by adding types to the `or_else` call, like so:
```rust
.or_else::<io::Error, _>(|err| {
    ...
```
